Domestic-offset leverage is used to facilitate access to modern weapons technology.
Procurement debates elevate technology transfer and co-production as criteria for judging major weapons deals.
Taiwan foregoes significant production shares in an F-16 deal in order to obtain the aircraft.
Technology-transfer/offset generosity declines relative to the Cold War period even as regional threats persist.
Offsets and licensing contribute to some domestic capability growth but have limited impact on achieving broad self-sufficiency or creating global high-technology competitors.
A more controlled offset structure is argued to better balance sales/political benefits with preservation of technological advantage.
Unrestrained offsets are portrayed as generating serious policy/security risks that can make long-run consequences intolerable.
A dedicated offsets management office is created to manage the F-18 programme and subsequent offset agreements.
The offsets management office is reframed/renamed toward industrial cooperation as Spain’s compensation strategy shifts away from offsets.
Offsets become central to publicly justifying the procurement decision.
Public dissemination of offset-progression information dwindles as the supplier falls behind commitments.
Offset content is partially steered toward higher-technology and technology-transfer activities.
Spanish public funds cover the difference between domestic and market costs for direct offsets.
Local assembly is ruled out, but Spain insists on aerospace-related offsets.
Spanish firms obtain work on export F-18s, supporting aerospace-component industry development.
Indirect commercial offsets create major management overhead and are later avoided where possible.
A substantial share of proposed offsets are rejected after administrative review.
The programme yields job creation effects, export/trade-balance mitigation, training, and improved market acceptance of Spanish defence-related products.
The Spanish administration reports difficulty assessing proposals and faces parliamentary challenges over eligibility; the programme is exposed to unforeseeable economic shocks.
Industrial cooperation programmes are managed differently from offsets and are described as less cumbersome to administer.
A firm’s offset-built expertise is used as the basis for its role in a subsequent cooperative programme.
Foreign firms take substantial minority stakes in Spanish defence firms as part of procurement-linked arrangements.
Long-term benefits from foreign participation may not accrue and can trigger visible investor dissatisfaction and exit threats.
Offsets persist but are increasingly limited to smaller transactions.
Offsets become concentrated in Madrid and among a small set of major firms.
Switzerland adopts offset commitments alongside foreign aircraft procurement (e.g., the F-5 acquisition).
The MOU provides trade-opening measures intended to enable Swiss firms to compete for offset-eligible work.
Progress toward meeting offset commitments is slow in the first several years and generates disappointments.
Swiss bids require explicit waiver labelling and Switzerland presses for publication of the MOU in US acquisition regulations.
Offset crediting excludes service industries (e.g., tourism) and emphasises defence-industrial base protection.
Indirect offsets account for most of the F-5 offset commitment while remaining targeted to defence-relevant firms.
Offset credit is conditioned on a causality/additionality test.
GE largely fulfils offsets within the parent corporation, while Northrop relies on subcontractors and marketing assistance to meet commitments.
Some offset approaches (including third-country parts/equipment provision) are curtailed by Swiss law.
US policy changes to place full responsibility for future offset commitments on the contracting firm (Duncan memorandum, 1978).
Offset goal increases to 50% with a liquidated-damages penalty (rendered moot when the goal is over-achieved).
DoD’s share of total offsets declines markedly from Peace Alps I to Peace Alps II.
Offsets support continued Swiss defence appropriations and facilitate approval of subsequent projects (e.g., F-18).
Some Swiss firms’ successes are followed by US Congressional retaliation via additional non-tariff barriers.
All major Swiss weapon-system purchases since 1976 include compensation/offset provisions.
Indirect offsets focus on market access and commonly take the form of purchases, marketing assistance, licensing, R&D collaboration, and training.
Offsets remain accepted with an implicit cost-premium ceiling (around 10%).
The offset-requirement threshold increases from 10 million to 50 million Swiss francs (early 1990s).
Swiss firms are required to sign statements attesting that purchases were made as part of an offset deal.
Required offset percentages rise over time (30% → 50% → 100% in the F-18 project).
Offsets may be viewed as a 'bad thing' in contexts where a domestic alternative exists.
There are few economic evaluations of offset programmes and evaluation is difficult.
Incoming vs outgoing offset impacts can be compared as a partial verification strategy.
The UK adopts an offset policy for imports, with the Harpoon missile cited as the first UK purchase to attract an offset.
The AWACS purchase is paired with a large offset commitment (ultimately 130% of purchase price over eight years).
Offset commitments do not guarantee orders for UK firms.
Only work meeting MoD criteria is eligible for offset credit.
Follow-on contracts receive discounted offset credit and industry/parliamentary actors dispute whether approved work is genuinely new business.
The Defence Committee expresses doubt that credited Rolls-Royce engine purchases occurred because of the offset.
Most AWACS offset value is indirect (about 95%).
The MoD initially did not monitor jobs created and DESO began monitoring only after parliamentary prompting.
A substantial discrepancy emerges between Boeing/MoD job claims and firm responses; an expert suggests genuinely new business is typically only a fraction of an offset.
DESO may allow anything from zero to 100% of claimed value, and UK firms cannot be certain which contracts are counted as offsets.
Small firms report higher offset-work shares of turnover than large firms; respondents report offset work is as profitable as other work.
Firms report that direct-inclusion offset sales are typically less than 5% (or zero) for most major recipients.
Most surveyed firms report offset sales did not improve competitiveness (or only marginally).
Survey respondents estimate total losses of about 626 employee-years across the sample and describe adverse employment impacts as trivial relative to offset value.

Offset obligations are reported as being met through various sources (prime/sub-contractors/other firms), and the chapter estimates combined losses to British industry (including subcontractors) on the order of ~1105 employee-years for the sample.
Overseas investment and counterpurchase can dominate fulfilment in such contexts.
Many respondents report technology transfer and some expect it to improve rivals’ competitiveness; some large firms report strategies to limit risk.
Respondents report discovering lower-cost sources in several cases and intending to continue business; short-term work is associated with uncompetitive suppliers.
Survey respondents call for broader UK offset requirements (including toward WEAG countries) and highlight high WEAG offset demands.
Respondents criticise the UK threshold (£10m), argue it should be lowered, and call for penalties; an example is given of multiple sub-threshold contracts avoiding UK offset obligations.
The chapter argues offsets are not costless and recommends seeking quotes at varying offset levels (e.g., 0%, 50%, 100%, 150%).
US offset policy is described as ambivalent 'benign neglect', with political concerns mounting over time.
The 1961 US–West Germany 'offset' agreements led German procurements from the US to offset roughly 80% of US force-cost balance-of-payments impacts in Germany.
Offset demands broaden to include technology transfer, investment/buyback, and political justification alongside balance-of-payments considerations.
For the Swiss F-5 purchase, the US Department of Defense agreed to act as guarantor for offset commitments; no such US government role was envisioned for the F-16 sale to a NATO consortium.
The Duncan Memorandum removed the US government from any back-up role for future offset commitments, placing full responsibility on the US firm.
By spring 1994, offset goals set at 100% or more of purchase price were not unusual.
Efforts to limit or abolish offsets are repeatedly frustrated and can result in US prime contractors resisting government attempts to 'help' by restricting offers.
A series of inter-agency offset reports was issued annually from 1986 through 1990, including case studies of major sales.
Commerce delayed issuing required regulations for about eighteen months; the chapter interprets this as evidence that offsets were a low priority in 1994.
No Section 825 notification regulations were ever prescribed; the chapter describes DoD as having 'stonewalled' on the issue.
Offset-related discussions under MOUs are described as largely 'fact-finding' and unlikely to change states’ offset practices.
A policy statement released on April 16, 1990 restated the Duncan Memorandum: the US government would not act as guarantor of firms’ offset commitments.
Despite agreeing to a 30% offset level, South Korea extracted purchases substantially exceeding 30%, illustrating the futility of unilateral control.
The NATO Code of Conduct made little progress toward eliminating offsets and is assessed as likely to achieve little even if adopted.
OMB concludes the total employment effects of offsets are minor and that the main effect is redistribution across sectors.
The chapter reports an assessment that offsets’ major effect is to strengthen existing competitors and expand their markets.
In 1994 Congress introduced new disclosure requirements and a ban on incentive payments, described as the first regulation of the substantive side of offsets.
In the Finland F/A-18 case, a proposed payment was perceived as a bribe and framed as falling between existing statutes, catalyzing attention to incentive-payment restrictions.
A 1994 GAO report attacked aid-recipient offset demands on aid-financed US weapons purchases, increasing congressional concern.

A July 1991 rule allowed recovery of offset administrative costs under FMS contracts when LOAs included specific notices and disclaimers, and later proposed revisions removed references to the LOA note.

US civilian countertrade guidance prohibits agencies from promoting countertrade but permits advisory/market services and generally does not oppose company participation absent national security concerns.
Reports mandated under Section 2205 were never published due to interagency disputes and the Commerce Office of Barter played no role in formulating offset policy.
North American source requirements are viewed as indistinguishable from standard offset requirements and fuel charges of US inconsistency.
Maryland (and later other states) established state-level offset-credit practices linked to foreign purchases.
The chapter describes a confusing tangle of offset-related laws and calls for a comprehensive review of legislation and regulations.
The chapter argues the parties’ positions can be reconciled and that offset execution improves when actors move away from adversarial postures.
High offset demands are described as increasing system costs and risking future restrictions on offset practices.
Contractors may submit misaligned proposals primarily to appease offset authorities rather than to create viable ventures.
Offsets can materially affect procurement outcomes and the profitability of major sales campaigns.
Typical offset commitment levels increase substantially, often exceeding requested levels by up to double or more.
Offsets are framed as a way for companies to compete beyond the product itself and can influence decisions between equipment of equal calibre.

The chapter describes a shift toward indirect offsets, citing the UAE program as making no requests for direct offsets and instead stressing profitability, technology transfer, and industrial diversification.
Offset authorities become uncomfortable with third-party fulfilment and develop credit limits and proof-of-causality requirements.
The chapter argues that offsets may persist even where they are not formally required because substantial offset proposals are expected on a 'voluntary' basis.
The chapter reports that in December 1994 US firms must report offset obligations above $5M and offset transactions credited at $250k or more.
A DoD LOA notification rule about offset administrative costs reportedly threatened a UAE helicopter sale and was dropped in 1994.
Israel’s primary offset goal is to foster close, long-term working relationships between foreign and Israeli firms to help Israeli companies grow.
Israel’s authority is described as emphasizing long-term relationships, with offset-driven initiatives reportedly maintained long after obligations are satisfied.
The Israeli ICA is described as monitoring industrial co-operation agreements and not approving or disapproving projects.
Israel requests 35% (or more) offsets, typically expects a 20/40/40 completion schedule over three years (extendable for large deals), and has no liquidated damages clause.
Israel credits direct purchases at 100%, offers higher credits for some R&D/investment/software activities, and limits transport and third-party credit shares.
Israel moves toward requiring offsets by law, described as targeting civil-sector companies that had refused to enter offset agreements.
The tender is described as creating a 'spiralling offset competition' and the authors frame indirect initiatives as a way to avoid the challenges associated with large direct offers.
The chapter argues offset proposals should not be generic and frames Israel as a favorable environment for offsets due to its technology base.
The offset basket is described as needing to target Russian immigrants/scientists and to provide immediate employment opportunities.
The chapter reports that the defense industry crisis seriously impacted the offset strategy and that the basket prioritized opportunities with defense entities.

The technology seminar and field work produced over 100 opportunities; the chapter claims offsets opened opportunities that would have gone unnoticed and some projects were executed before platform selection.
The chapter asserts offsets will not sway IAF procurement unless systems are perceived as equal and links this to the F-15E/I choice once export approval was granted.
Evaluation of offset programmes is described as 'incredibly difficult', with limited publicly available information in many cases.
The chapter states that when eligible work merely reflects existing business relations, the impact of an offset is likely to be trivial.
The chapter notes reluctance to admit offsets cost more than an off-the-shelf purchase and frames this as central to assessing cost effectiveness.
The chapter describes a shift from 'best endeavours' to using financial penalties as a better incentive for non-fulfilment.
The chapter reports that erroneous beliefs about guaranteed orders led to widespread disenchantment when such sales did not materialise.
Administering offset programmes is described as onerous, with inevitable disputes about whether work is 'new work' and how to value/assess it.
The chapter states that agreeing a package in advance is 'not practical' for a $1 billion indirect offset.
The chapter reports a move away from general offset programmes toward more focused measures.
The chapter notes that many countries allow a firm to bank offset credit and frames this as a response to short-termism.
The chapter reports that countries seek equity investments and joint ventures to induce foreign firms to share technological and marketing skills and continue placing work domestically.
The chapter argues that the move toward joint ventures 'does not reflect the failure of the former; rather, the reverse.'
The chapter concludes offsets are unlikely to disappear in the foreseeable future and that 'competitive pressures will force vendors' to meet offset demands.
